qas.question: Hayek believed that authoritarianism was very different from what?
What country did Hayek arrive in where he provided his disctinction between totalitarianism and authoritarianism?
What did Hayek believe to be absent from Latin America?
What is Hayek's definition of totalitarian?

answers.text: the want to “organize the whole of society” to attain a “definite social goal”

context: For Hayek, the supposedly stark difference between authoritarianism and <a0_0>totalitarianism<a0_0/> has much importance and Hayek places heavy weight on this distinction in his defence of transitional dictatorship. For example, when Hayek visited <a1_0>Venezuela<a1_0/> in May 1981, he was asked to comment on the prevalence of totalitarian regimes in Latin America. In reply, Hayek warned against confusing "totalitarianism with authoritarianism," and said that he was unaware of "any <a2_0>totalitarian governments<a2_0/> in Latin America. The only one was Chile under Allende". For Hayek, however, the word 'totalitarian' signifies something very specific: <a3_0>the want to “organize the whole of society” to attain a “definite social goal”<a3_0/> —which is stark in contrast to “liberalism and individualism”.
